title: Reps. Scalise and Richmond say their friendship and faith are an example for Congress
content:
WASHINGTON — With a Democrat by his side , Republican leader Steve Scalise , who narrowly survived a gunshot last summer , called on his colleagues Thursday to put prayer and faith at the center of their lives even when they disagree .
The Louisiana Republican pointed to what he called the `` great bond '' he shares with Rep. Cedric Richmond , a Democrat from Louisiana .
`` Hopefully it serves as a lesson to all that sure we have differences , but differences are what make our country great , '' Scalise said . `` The fact that we ’ re able to express our faiths that might be different , to fight for the things that we believe in … I think we all want to get to the same place . We just sometimes have different roads that we take to get there . ’ ’
Scalise , the majority whip , spoke to a roomful of members of Congress and others at the National Prayer Breakfast in Washington , D.C. Thousands of politicians , dignitaries and faith leaders attend the annual affair .
Across town , Congress is battling over a spending bill , immigration reforms and Russian investigations . Scalise urged his colleagues to turn to their faith .
“ We do not check our faith at the door when we enter civic life , ” he told the crowd .
And in a nod to putting friendship over partisanship , Richmond , the lone Democrat in Louisiana 's congressional delegation , praised Scalise in his introduction of his colleague .
Richmond said many wonder how he and Scalise are such great friends when they disagree on about 80 percent of the issues .
“ We don ’ t differ on the end goal of helping the needy and protecting our citizens and caring for our elders . We don ’ t disagree on where we want to end up . Most times we disagree on how to get there , '' he said .
“ Our faith unites us . Our faith allows us to put purpose first . We put purpose over politics . ''
Scalise , a conservative , spends his days trying to persuade his colleagues to support GOP policies , including dismantling the Affordable Care Act . He was a frequent critic of former President Obama ’ s policies .
Richmond , chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus , rallies his colleagues to challenge Republican efforts to undo the federal health care laws and others programs . And he ’ s regularly at odds with President Trump .
But Scalise often teams with Richmond to address state issues , including fighting for more federal disaster aid .
Their friendship goes back to the Louisiana legislature , where the two served and bonded over efforts to get aid after Hurricane Katrina . Their families have even traveled together on vacation .
Richmond was one of the first to arrive at the hospital last June when Scalise was transported there after he was shot on a baseball field .
Scalise , who was playing second base , was practicing with his Republican teammates at a ballfield in a Virginia suburb when he was shot in the leg . He has undergone several surgeries , including some to save his life , and months of rehabilitation .
He returned last fall to the House , where his colleagues greeted him with a standing ovation . Richmond stood behind him on the House floor .
Scalise said he prayed when he laid on the baseball field unable to move . He said he prayed to see his family again , for the Capitol Police officers protecting them and his colleagues also on the ballfield .
“ In that moment , it gave me a remarkable sense of calm to know that it was in God ’ s hands , ’ ’ he said .
Scalise thanked the thousands who prayed for him and rallied behind him during his months of recovery .
“ When you pray for somebody you don ’ t know - they feel it… , '' he said . `` I felt that prayer . ”
Minutes later , Scalise headed back to the U.S. Capitol to meet with House Speaker Paul Ryan , R-Wisc. , and rally his colleagues to support a long-awaited budget deal .
“ I feel good that we ’ re going to have a strong vote today . You still got to do your job in addition to battling through recovery and sharing my faith… , ’ ’ Scalise said as he rode back to the Capitol . “ Cedric ought to vote for this bill today . I might actually get his vote today . We ’ ll see what happens . ”
content_original:
Deborah Barfield Berry

USA TODAY

WASHINGTON — With a Democrat by his side, Republican leader Steve Scalise, who narrowly survived a gunshot last summer, called on his colleagues Thursday to put prayer and faith at the center of their lives even when they disagree.

The Louisiana Republican pointed to what he called the "great bond'' he shares with Rep. Cedric Richmond, a Democrat from Louisiana.

"Hopefully it serves as a lesson to all that sure we have differences, but differences are what make our country great,'' Scalise said. "The fact that we’re able to express our faiths that might be different, to fight for the things that we believe in … I think we all want to get to the same place. We just sometimes have different roads that we take to get there.’’

Scalise, the majority whip, spoke to a roomful of members of Congress and others at the National Prayer Breakfast in Washington, D.C. Thousands of politicians, dignitaries and faith leaders attend the annual affair.

Across town, Congress is battling over a spending bill, immigration reforms and Russian investigations. Scalise urged his colleagues to turn to their faith.

“We do not check our faith at the door when we enter civic life,” he told the crowd.

And in a nod to putting friendship over partisanship, Richmond, the lone Democrat in Louisiana's congressional delegation, praised Scalise in his introduction of his colleague.

Richmond said many wonder how he and Scalise are such great friends when they disagree on about 80 percent of the issues.

“We don’t differ on the end goal of helping the needy and protecting our citizens and caring for our elders. We don’t disagree on where we want to end up. Most times we disagree on how to get there," he said.

“Our faith unites us. Our faith allows us to put purpose first. We put purpose over politics.''

Their politics couldn’t be more different.

Scalise, a conservative, spends his days trying to persuade his colleagues to support GOP policies, including dismantling the Affordable Care Act. He was a frequent critic of former President Obama’s policies.

Richmond, chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus, rallies his colleagues to challenge Republican efforts to undo the federal health care laws and others programs. And he’s regularly at odds with President Trump.

But Scalise often teams with Richmond to address state issues, including fighting for more federal disaster aid.

Their friendship goes back to the Louisiana legislature, where the two served and bonded over efforts to get aid after Hurricane Katrina. Their families have even traveled together on vacation.

Richmond was one of the first to arrive at the hospital last June when Scalise was transported there after he was shot on a baseball field.

Scalise, who was playing second base, was practicing with his Republican teammates at a ballfield in a Virginia suburb when he was shot in the leg. He has undergone several surgeries, including some to save his life, and months of rehabilitation.

He returned last fall to the House, where his colleagues greeted him with a standing ovation. Richmond stood behind him on the House floor.

Scalise said he prayed when he laid on the baseball field unable to move. He said he prayed to see his family again, for the Capitol Police officers protecting them and his colleagues also on the ballfield.

“In that moment, it gave me a remarkable sense of calm to know that it was in God’s hands,’’ he said.

Scalise thanked the thousands who prayed for him and rallied behind him during his months of recovery.

“When you pray for somebody you don’t know - they feel it…,'' he said. "I felt that prayer.”

Minutes later, Scalise headed back to the U.S. Capitol to meet with House Speaker Paul Ryan, R-Wisc., and rally his colleagues to support a long-awaited budget deal.

“I feel good that we’re going to have a strong vote today. You still got to do your job in addition to battling through recovery and sharing my faith…,’’ Scalise said as he rode back to the Capitol. “Cedric ought to vote for this bill today. I might actually get his vote today. We’ll see what happens. ”
